elements.content: Trinuclear chiral (LH)2­L2Cu3 (LH = 1,3-diamino-2-propanol, bdapH) assemblies linked by octacyanidometalate(IV) form isostructural one-dimensional (1D) chains consisting of right- and left-handed helixes arranged in an alternate manner: [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]­[MIV­(CN)8]·​H2O (M = Mo 1, W 2). Each chain displays helicity with a long pitch around 17.2 Å. The direction of the helix rotation is strictly connected with the conformation of the (LH)2­L2Cu3 unit. Right-handed helixes are based on Δ-S,S-(LH)2­L2Cu3, whereas left-handed ones contain Λ-R,R-(LH)2­L2Cu3 units. Magnetic studies reveal antiferromagnetic interactions through alkoxo-bridges inside trinuclear Cu(II) nodes leading to an S T = 1/2 ground state for both assemblies.

Each chain displays helicity with a long pitch around 17.2 Å. The direction of the helix rotation is strictly connected with the conformation of the (LH)2L2Cu3 unit. Right-handed helixes are based on Δ-S,S-(LH)2L2Cu3, whereas left-handed ones contain Λ-R,R-(LH)2L2Cu3 units. Magnetic studies reveal antiferromagnetic interactions through alkoxo-bridges inside trinuclear Cu(II) nodes leading to an S  T  = 1/2 ground state for both assemblies.

Magnetic studies reveal antiferromagnetic interactions inside trinuclear Cu(II) nodes leading to an S T = 1/2 ground state for both assemblies.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of chiral magnetic materials combining magnetism and optical activity is one of the major challenges in the pursuit of polyfunctional materials. In this field, extensive research is related to cyanido-bridged coordination polymers based on octacyanidometalates, which exhibit coexistence of chirality with a broad range of magnetic properties, including long-range magnetic ordering, magnetic anisotropy, and photomagnetism. Since the chirality of the compounds must be controlled in the molecular structure, as well as in the entire crystal structure, the access to chiral cyanido-based magnets is not trivial. The reported synthetic strategies comprise programmed coordination of chiral ligands to 3d/4f metal centers, followed by self-assembly with octacyanidometalates and serendipitous formation of noncentrosymmetric networks employing achiral ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of chiral magnetic materials combining magnetism and optical activity is one of the major challenges in the pursuit of polyfunctional materials. In this field, extensive research is related to cyanido-bridged coordination polymers based on octacyanidometalates, which exhibit coexistence of chirality with a broad range of magnetic properties, including long-range magnetic ordering, magnetic anisotropy, and photomagnetism. Since the chirality of the compounds must be controlled in the molecular structure, as well as in the entire crystal structure, the access to chiral cyanido-based magnets is not trivial. The reported synthetic strategies comprise programmed coordination of chiral ligands to 3d/4f metal centers, followed by self-assembly with octacyanidometalates and serendipitous formation of noncentrosymmetric networks employing achiral ligands.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, the only example of the chiral helical system obtained from a chiral ligand is the 1D chain {[EuIII­(R,R/S,S-Pr i -Pybox)­(dmf)4]3­[WV­(CN)8]3} n ·​dmf·​8H2O (Pr i -Pybox = 2,2′-(2,6-pyridine­diyl)­bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline), dmf = dimethylformamide). The majority of helical bimetallic magnetic systems based on [M­(CN)8] n− building blocks were generated from achiral ligands, such as polyamines, polyimines, Schiff bases, and macrocycles. Generally, they crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups due to self-assembly of right- (Δ) and left-handed (Λ) helixes in an alternate manner. However, spontaneous chiral resolution was reported for [LnIII­(dmf)6]­[MoV­(CN)8] (LnIII = Pr, Nd), [NiII­(tren)]3­[MoIV­(CN)8]­(ClO4)2·​5H2O (tren = tris(2-amino­ethyl)­amine), and [CuII­(tren)]­[CuII­(bapa)]­[MoIV(CN)8]·​4H2O (bapa = bis(3-amino­propyl)­amine). Additionally, in the Cu(II)-Mo(IV) systems, a photomagnetic effect was observed.
elements.clean_text: To the best of our knowledge, the only example of the chiral helical system obtained from a chiral ligand is the 1D chain {[EuIII(R,R/S,S-Pr i -Pybox)(dmf)4]3[WV(CN)8]3} n ⋅dmf⋅8H2O (Pr i -Pybox = 2,2'-(2,6-pyridinediyl)bis(4-isopropyl-2-oxazoline), dmf = dimethylformamide). The majority of helical bimetallic magnetic systems based on [M(CN)8] n- building blocks were generated from achiral ligands, such as polyamines, polyimines, Schiff bases, and macrocycles. Generally, they crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups due to self-assembly of right- (Δ) and left-handed (Λ) helixes in an alternate manner. However, spontaneous chiral resolution was reported for [LnIII(dmf)6][MoV(CN)8] (LnIII = Pr, Nd), [NiII(tren)]3[MoIV(CN)8](ClO4)2⋅5H2O (tren = tris(2-aminoethyl)amine), and [CuII(tren)][CuII(bapa)][MoIV(CN)8]⋅4H2O (bapa = bis(3-aminopropyl)amine). Additionally, in the Cu(II)-Mo(IV) systems, a photomagnetic effect was observed.

elements.content: In this context, we decided to obtain novel magnetic materials based on chiral polynuclear magnetic Cu(II)–aminoalcohol assemblies. Copper(II) ions with aminoalcohols (L) form numerous polynuclear alkoxo-bridged Cu x L y (2 ≤ x ≤ 6, y ≥ x) systems ensuring strong magnetic coupling. In particular, Cu(II) complexes with aminoalcohols, such as H3Tea (triethanolamine) and Hea (ethanolamine), have proven to be successful building blocks for the self-assembly of octacyanidometalate-based coordination polymers. [CuII 2­(H2Tea)2]5­[WV­(CN)8]2­[WIV­(CN)8]·​xH2O and [CuII­(ea)]4­[MIV­(CN)8]·​2H2O (M = Mo, W) are structurally characterized as 3D networks based on alkoxo-bridged dimers (Cu2L2)-[Cu2­(H2­Tea)2]2+ and cubes (Cu4­L4)-[Cu­(ea)]4 4+, linked by [M­(CN)8]4–/3– ions. The assembly built from Cu2L2 dimers exhibits antiferromagnetic ordering below 2.2 K, whereas compounds with the Cu4L4 units behave like high-spin molecules with S = 2 bridged by diamagnetic octacyanidometalate(IV) ions.
elements.clean_text: In this context, we decided to obtain novel magnetic materials based on chiral polynuclear magnetic Cu(II)-aminoalcohol assemblies. Copper(II) ions with aminoalcohols (L) form numerous polynuclear alkoxo-bridged Cu x L y  (2 ≤ x ≤ 6, y ≥ x) systems ensuring strong magnetic coupling. In particular, Cu(II) complexes with aminoalcohols, such as H3Tea (triethanolamine) and Hea (ethanolamine), have proven to be successful building blocks for the self-assembly of octacyanidometalate-based coordination polymers. [CuII 2(H2Tea)2]5[WV(CN)8]2[WIV(CN)8]⋅xH2O and [CuII(ea)]4[MIV(CN)8]⋅2H2O (M = Mo, W) are structurally characterized as 3D networks based on alkoxo-bridged dimers (Cu2L2)-[Cu2(H2Tea)2]2+ and cubes (Cu4L4)-[Cu(ea)]4 4+, linked by [M(CN)8]4-/3- ions. The assembly built from Cu2L2 dimers exhibits antiferromagnetic ordering below 2.2 K, whereas compounds with the Cu4L4 units behave like high-spin molecules with S = 2 bridged by diamagnetic octacyanidometalate(IV) ions.

elements.content: Herein, we focus our interest on the unexplored trinuclear [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­Cu3]4+ compound revealing an ability to form Δ and Λ spiral structures. The coordination of 1,3-diamino-2-propanol (bdapH) to Cu(II) leads to triangular (L3Cu3) and spiral ((LH)2­L2Cu3) trinuclear complexes (Figure ). The sterical hindrance between terminal bdapH ligands in spiral (LH)2­L2Cu3 units induces chirality on two carbon atoms located on bridging bdap molecules. Hence, the spiral (LH)2­L2Cu3 unit consists of the right-handed (Δ) form of S,S configurations on chiral carbon atoms, and the left-handed (Λ) form of R,R configurations in the two enantiomorphic forms. To the best of our knowledge, the spiral form of (LH)2­L2Cu3 has never been applied in the synthesis of coordination polymers. Therefore, we decided to connect the trinuclear moiety with octacyanidometalates(IV) with the expectation that novel magnetic properties would be added to those found in the Cu(II)-Mo(IV) systems. As a result, we obtained 1D helical chains of [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]­[MIV­(CN)8]·​H2O (M = Mo 1, W 2) that are the very first examples of a polynuclear chiral building block presence in octacyanidometalate-based systems. Structural, spectroscopic, and magnetic properties are reported and discussed.

Hence, the spiral (LH)2L2Cu3 unit consists of the right-handed (Δ) form of S,S configurations on chiral carbon atoms, and the left-handed (Λ) form of R,R configurations in the two enantiomorphic forms. elements.content: All starting materials were commercially available, reagent grade, and used as purchased without further purification. Potassium octacyanidotungstate(IV) and octacyanidomolybdate(IV) salts have been prepared according to the published procedures. The [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]I4·​CH3OH ((LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 ), as a reference compound for magnetic measurements, has been synthesized according to the published procedure (, Experimental Section).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All starting materials were commercially available, reagent grade, and used as purchased without further purification. Potassium octacyanidotungstate(IV) and octacyanidomolybdate(IV) salts have been prepared according to the published procedures. The [(bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3]I4⋅CH3OH ((LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 ), as a reference compound for magnetic measurements, has been synthesized according to the published procedure (, Experimental Section).

elements.content: Infrared spectra were recorded in KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 using a Bruker EQUINOX 55 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out with an Elementery Vario Micro Cube CHNS. Diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 UV/vis spectrophotometer equipped with a PerkinElmer Labsphere RSA-PE-20 Reflectance Spectroscopy Accessory and converted with a Kubelka–Munk function. Magnetic measurements on polycrystalline samples were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. All experimental magnetic data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the sample holders and of the constituent atoms (Pascal’s tables). Photomagnetic studies were performed on a powdered sample of 1 placed as a thin layer between two transparent films (around 3 mg). Experiments were done with 405, 450, 660, and 843 nm laser diodes, and with 473 and 532 nm diode-pumped solid-state lasers (P = 25 mW/cm2) coupled through an optical fiber directed into the magnetometer cavity. Experimental data were corrected for sample holder and diamagnetic contribution of the samples using experimentally determined values.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Techniques

Infrared spectra were recorded in KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 using a Bruker EQUINOX 55 FT-IR spectrometer. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were carried out with an Elementery Vario Micro Cube CHNS. Diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 UV/vis spectrophotometer equipped with a PerkinElmer Labsphere RSA-PE-20 Reflectance Spectroscopy Accessory and converted with a Kubelka-Munk function. Magnetic measurements on polycrystalline samples were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. All experimental magnetic data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the sample holders and of the constituent atoms (Pascal's tables). Photomagnetic studies were performed on a powdered sample of 1 placed as a thin layer between two transparent films (around 3 mg). Experiments were done with 405, 450, 660, and 843 nm laser diodes, and with 473 and 532 nm diode-pumped solid-state lasers (P = 25 mW/cm2) coupled through an optical fiber directed into the magnetometer cavity. Experimental data were corrected for sample holder and diamagnetic contribution of the samples using experimentally determined values.

[(bdapH)<sub>2</sub>­(bdap)<sub>2</sub>­Cu<sup>II</sup> <sub>3</sub>]­[Mo<sup>IV</sup>­(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·​H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

To the aqueous solution (16 mL) containing Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O (37 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1,3-diamino-2-propanol (45 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added K4­[Mo­(CN)8]·​2H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol, 4 mL of H2O) slowly upon vigorous stirring. The dark blue solution was left undisturbed for slow evaporation in a dark place. Navy blue crystals of 1 were obtained after a few weeks. The product was filtrated, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield of 1: 21.8 mg (75% based on Cu). Elementary Anal. Calcd. for C20H40­Cu3­MoN16O5 (871.21 g/mol): C, 27.57; H, 4.63; N, 25.72%; found: C, 27.36; H, 4.67; N, 25.64%. IR of 1 (KBr, cm–1): 3462s(br), 3303vs(br) [ν(O–H), ν(N–H)]; 3125m, 2924m, 2880w, 2851m [ν(C–H)]; 2124vs, 2109m, 2096vs, 2083vs [ν(CN)]; 1600s, 1574s [γ(O–H)]; 1452m, 1413w, 1385w, 1353w, 1330w, 1307m, 1285w, 1219w [δ(H–C–H), ν(N–C), ν(C–C)]; 1187m, 1151w, 1086m, 1049s, 1027s, 962m, 931w, 893w, 847m, 803s, 731s, 635w [γ(N–H out-of-plane), ν(N–C)]; 537m, 505m [ν(Mo–C), ν(Cu–N)]. Solid-state UV–vis-NIR of 1 (nm): 256, 369 [MLCT band of [Mo­(CN)8]4–]; 430 [MMCT band in Cu(II)-Mo(IV) pair]; 710, 823 [d–d bands of (LH)2­L2Cu3] (, Figure S4).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed with a Bruker APEX II 4476 diffractometer for 1, and a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer for 2, operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using graphite monochromated molybdenum radiation [λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å]. Data collection and reduction were performed using BRUKER SUIT (APEX II) and Denzo and Scalepack (KappaCCD) programs. The structure was solved by direct methods using the package WinGX (SIR-97; SHELXL-97) and refined by F 2 full-matrix refinement. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon and nitrogen atoms of the organic component of 1 and 2 were positioned with an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms of crystallization water molecules are unreachable, so their positions were calculated with the XHYDEX program or manually at positions optimized to form the hydrogen bonds and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, data collection, and refinement parameters for 1 and 2 are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table . CCDC 978521–978522 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The structural data presented as figures are prepared with the use of the CCDC Mercury visualization software. Geometries of metal centers are estimated with the Continuous Shape Measures (CShM) analysis with the use of SHAPE v2.0 software (, Tables S1 and S2).

X-ray Crystallography

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed with a Bruker APEX II 4476 diffractometer for 1, and a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer for 2, operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using graphite monochromated molybdenum radiation [λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å]. Data collection and reduction were performed using BRUKER SUIT (APEX II) and Denzo and Scalepack (KappaCCD) programs. The structure was solved by direct methods using the package WinGX (SIR-97; SHELXL-97) and refined by F 2 full-matrix refinement. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. All hydrogen atoms joined to carbon and nitrogen atoms of the organic component of 1 and 2 were positioned with an idealized geometry and refined using a riding model. Hydrogen atoms of crystallization water molecules are unreachable, so their positions were calculated with the XHYDEX program or manually at positions optimized to form the hydrogen bonds and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, data collection, and refinement parameters for 1 and 2 are listed in Table , and selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table . CCDC 978521-978522 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. The structural data presented as figures are prepared with the use of the CCDC Mercury visualization software. Geometries of metal centers are estimated with the Continuous Shape Measures (CShM) analysis with the use of SHAPE v2.0 software (, Tables S1 and S2).

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 and 2 are isomorphous, and they form structures containing 1D right- (Δ) and left-handed (Λ) helixes arranged in an alternate manner (Figure ). Each chain is built of [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­Cu3]4+ trinuclear units bridged by [M­(CN)8]4– ions of triangular dodecahedron (TDD-8) geometry (, Figure S1, Table S1). Interestingly, each chain displays helicity with a long pitch around 17.2 Å for 1 and 2. The direction of the helix rotation is strictly connected with the conformation of the (LH)2L2Cu3 unit. Right-handed helixes are based on Δ-S,S-(LH)2­L2Cu3, whereas left-handed ones contain Λ-R,R-(LH)2­L2Cu3 units. This observation leads to the conclusion that chirality is transferred from structural entities to helical chains. The octacyanidometalate(IV) anion forms one cyanido-bridge (C1–N1) to the Cu1 center and one μ3-cyanido-bridge (C2–N2) to the Cu2 and Cu3 centers (, Figure S2). An analogous bridging mode was observed for (LH)2­L2Cu3 assemblies with NO2 – and SCN– ions. Average M–C and C–N bond distances in M–C–N–Cu linkages are 2.166 and 1.152 Å, respectively, while M–C–N angles are almost 180°. Each copper(II) center reveals a different 5-coordinate geometry: square-pyramidal (SPY-5) for Cu1, trigonal-bipyramidal (TBPY-5) for Cu2, and intermediate between square-pyramidal (SPY-5) and vacant octahedral (vOC-5) for Cu3 (, Table S2). The equatorial positions in terminal [Cu(NC)(bdapH)(bdap)] units for Cu1 and Cu3 centers are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of chelating bdapH and one nitrogen and one oxygen atom of bridging bdap with an average Cu–L distance of 2.001 Å, while the axial one is occupied by nitrogen of the cyanido-bridge with Cu–N bond lengths in the range of 2.330(1)–2.567(3) Å. In the case of the central [Cu(NC)(bdap)2] moiety for Cu2 center, equatorial positions are occupied by oxygen and nitrogen atoms of two different bridging bdap ligands and a nitrogen atom of CN–, while the axial ones are coordinated by oxygen and nitrogen of bdap bridges with an average Cu2–L distance of 2.048 Å. All CN–-bridges are strongly bent, revealing Cu–N–C angles ranging between 137.72(12)° and 142.27(13)°. In structures of 1 and 2, long μ3-cyanido-bridges with CuX–N distances ranging from 2.2892(14) to 2.567(3) Å and Cu2–N2–Cu3 angles of 82.81(4)° and 82.68(8)° for 1 and 2, respectively, are present. For both compounds, the Cu1–O–Cu2 and Cu2–O–Cu3 angles are about 128.6° and 109.1°, respectively, whereas the analogous angles for (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 are 118.2° and 114.4°. The average Cu–O bond length in the μ-alkoxo-bridges in 1 and 2 of 1.983 Å conforms to those reported previously for (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 . Additionally, the hydrogen-bonding network stabilizes the structure due to interactions between bdapH ligands, water molecules, and nitrogen atoms of terminal CN– (, Figure S3).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of 1 and 2 

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that 1 and 2 are isomorphous, and they form structures containing 1D right- (Δ) and left-handed (Λ) helixes arranged in an alternate manner (Figure ). Each chain is built of [(bdapH)2(bdap)2Cu3]4+ trinuclear units bridged by [M(CN)8]4- ions of triangular dodecahedron (TDD-8) geometry (, Figure S1, Table S1). Interestingly, each chain displays helicity with a long pitch around 17.2 Å for 1 and 2. The direction of the helix rotation is strictly connected with the conformation of the (LH)2L2Cu3 unit. Right-handed helixes are based on Δ-S,S-(LH)2L2Cu3, whereas left-handed ones contain Λ-R,R-(LH)2L2Cu3 units. This observation leads to the conclusion that chirality is transferred from structural entities to helical chains. The octacyanidometalate(IV) anion forms one cyanido-bridge (C1-N1) to the Cu1 center and one μ3-cyanido-bridge (C2-N2) to the Cu2 and Cu3 centers (, Figure S2). An analogous bridging mode was observed for (LH)2L2Cu3 assemblies with NO2 - and SCN- ions. Average M-C and C-N bond distances in M-C-N-Cu linkages are 2.166 and 1.152 Å, respectively, while M-C-N angles are almost 180°. Each copper(II) center reveals a different 5-coordinate geometry: square-pyramidal (SPY-5) for Cu1, trigonal-bipyramidal (TBPY-5) for Cu2, and intermediate between square-pyramidal (SPY-5) and vacant octahedral (vOC-5) for Cu3 (, Table S2). The equatorial positions in terminal [Cu(NC)(bdapH)(bdap)] units for Cu1 and Cu3 centers are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of chelating bdapH and one nitrogen and one oxygen atom of bridging bdap with an average Cu-L distance of 2.001 Å, while the axial one is occupied by nitrogen of the cyanido-bridge with Cu-N bond lengths in the range of 2.330(1)-2.567(3) Å. In the case of the central [Cu(NC)(bdap)2] moiety for Cu2 center, equatorial positions are occupied by oxygen and nitrogen atoms of two different bridging bdap ligands and a nitrogen atom of CN-, while the axial ones are coordinated by oxygen and nitrogen of bdap bridges with an average Cu2-L distance of 2.048 Å. All CN--bridges are strongly bent, revealing Cu-N-C angles ranging between 137.72(12)° and 142.27(13)°. In structures of 1 and 2, long μ3-cyanido-bridges with CuX-N distances ranging from 2.2892(14) to 2.567(3) Å and Cu2-N2-Cu3 angles of 82.81(4)° and 82.68(8)° for 1 and 2, respectively, are present. For both compounds, the Cu1-O-Cu2 and Cu2-O-Cu3 angles are about 128.6° and 109.1°, respectively, whereas the analogous angles for (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4  are 118.2° and 114.4°. The average Cu-O bond length in the μ-alkoxo-bridges in 1 and 2 of 1.983 Å conforms to those reported previously for (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 . Additionally, the hydrogen-bonding network stabilizes the structure due to interactions between bdapH ligands, water molecules, and nitrogen atoms of terminal CN- (, Figure S3).

elements.content: The magnetic properties of polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 were investigated by measuring the thermal dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility χM in the temperature range of 1.8–300 K and at a magnetic field of 1 kOe. The results in the form of the χM T product per CuII 3L4MIV unit versus temperature are shown in Figure . The data for 1 and 2 have been compared to the magnetic properties of the molecular complex (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 . The χM T values at 300 K reach 0.93, 0.94, and 0.92 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 , respectively, which are much lower than the expected Curie constant value of 1.13 cm3 K mol–1 for three noninteracting spins S Cu = 1/2 with g = 2.0. At low temperatures, χ M T curves decrease to reach 0.40, 0.41, and 0.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K for 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 , respectively. These values are consistent with the Curie constant for a ground state of S T = 1/2, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling inside the (LH)2­L2Cu3 assemblies. The field dependencies of magnetization for 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 confirm these observations (Figure ). The saturation magnetization in a magnetic field of 50 kOe reached values around 1.0 Nβ for all compounds. Fits of the Brillouin function to the experimental data with S T = 1/2 give g values equal 2.06(1), 2.08(1), and 2.08(1) for 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 , respectively.

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 were investigated by measuring the thermal dependence of the molar magnetic susceptibility χM in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K and at a magnetic field of 1 kOe. The results in the form of the χM T product per CuII 3L4MIV unit versus temperature are shown in Figure . The data for 1 and 2 have been compared to the magnetic properties of the molecular complex (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 . The χM T values at 300 K reach 0.93, 0.94, and 0.92 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 2, and (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 , respectively, which are much lower than the expected Curie constant value of 1.13 cm3 K mol-1 for three noninteracting spins S Cu = 1/2 with g = 2.0. At low temperatures, χ M  T curves decrease to reach 0.40, 0.41, and 0.40 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K for 1, 2, and (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 , respectively. These values are consistent with the Curie constant for a ground state of S  T  = 1/2, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling inside the (LH)2L2Cu3 assemblies. The field dependencies of magnetization for 1, 2, and (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4  confirm these observations (Figure ). The saturation magnetization in a magnetic field of 50 kOe reached values around 1.0 Nβ for all compounds. Fits of the Brillouin function to the experimental data with S  T  = 1/2 give g values equal 2.06(1), 2.08(1), and 2.08(1) for 1, 2, and (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 , respectively.

elements.content: On the basis of the structural analysis, thermal dependencies of the susceptibility were analyzed in the terms of trinuclear systems defined by the following Hamiltonian: H = −2J 1 S 1 S 2 – 2J 2 S 2 S 3 assuming Heisenberg exchange interactions between adjacent CuII centers (Figure ). From this Hamiltonian, the χM T product of the trimer is calculated as χ M T = N A μ B 2 g 2 4 k 1 + exp ( − Δ 1 / k T ) + 10 exp ( − Δ 2 / k T ) 1 + exp ( − Δ 1 / k T ) + 2 exp ( − Δ 2 / k T ) with Δ 1 = − 2 J 1 2 + J 2 2 − J 1 J 2 and Δ 2 = Δ 1 2 − ( J 1 + J 2 ) where N A is Avogadro’s number, μB is the Bohr magneton, and k is the Boltzmann constant.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the structural analysis, thermal dependencies of the susceptibility were analyzed in the terms of trinuclear systems defined by the following Hamiltonian: H = -2J 1 S 1 S 2 - 2J 2 S 2 S 3 assuming Heisenberg exchange interactions between adjacent CuII centers (Figure ). From this Hamiltonian, the χM T product of the trimer is calculated as     χ   M   T =     N   A       μ   B     2     g   2     4 k     1 + exp  ( -   Δ   1   / k T )  + 10  exp  ( -   Δ   2   / k T )    1 + exp  ( -   Δ   1   / k T )  + 2  exp  ( -   Δ   2   / k T )        with    Δ   1   = - 2       J   1     2   +     J   2     2   -   J   1     J   2      and     Δ   2   =     Δ   1     2   - (   J   1   +   J   2   )  where N A is Avogadro's number, μB is the Bohr magneton, and k is the Boltzmann constant.

elements.content: An attempt to fit this model to the experimental data for 1 leads to two different solutions: the first J 1 = −110(11) K, J 2 = −90(13) K, and the second J 1 = J 2 = −100 K, with a large fitting error. The qualities of both fits are almost the same. Such ambiguity is a result of overparametrization of the experimental data. It is also not possible to distinguish which J value corresponds to which of the two different Cu–O–Cu bridges. The analysis of the data for 2 leads to similar results. Therefore, a simplest model was used with the additional assumption of J 1 = J 2 = J. The average values obtained are: J = −100(2) K, g = 2.09(1) for 1; J = −100(2) K, g = 2.10(1) for 2; and J = −118(1) K, g = 2.11(1) for (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 . The obtained J value for (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 agrees well with the previously reported results. The magnetic properties of 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 are dominated by the strong antiferromagnetic coupling through the alkoxo bridges whose geometry leads to a significant overlap between the magnetic orbitals.

elements.content: The possible existence of the photomagnetic effect in 1 was thoroughly investigated. The measurements were performed at 10 K, with an applied field of 10 kOe using the following wavelengths of irradiation lines: 405, 450, 473, 532, 660, and 843 nm at P = 25 mW/cm2, each irradiation lasting 1 h. These particular wavelengths were chosen based on the UV–vis-NIR characteristics of 1 (, Figure S4). No photomagnetic effect for 1 was observed in the experimental conditions employed ( , Figure S5).

The measurements were performed at 10 K, with an applied field of 10 kOe using the following wavelengths of irradiation lines: 405, 450, 473, 532, 660, and 843 nm at P = 25 mW/cm2, each irradiation lasting 1 h. These particular wavelengths were chosen based on the UV-vis-NIR characteristics of 1 (, Figure S4). No photomagnetic effect for 1 was observed in the experimental conditions employed ( , Figure S5).

elements.content: As a part of our studies aimed at the synthesis of coordination polymers containing chiral building blocks and octacyanidometalates, we report two novel 1D helical chains [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]­[MIV­(CN)8]·​H2O (M = Mo 1, W 2). The spiral intrinsically chiral (bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3 trinuclear nodes transfer chirality from the trinuclear nodes to the helical chains. To the best of our knowledge, the helical chains [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]­[MIV­(CN)8]·​H2O are the first examples of the presence of polynuclear chiral building blocks in octacyanidometalate-based systems. Magnetic studies of 1, 2, and previously reported [(bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3]I4·​CH3OH ((LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 ) reveal antiferromagnetic interactions inside the (bdapH)2­(bdap)2­CuII 3 units with J values equal to −100(2), −100(2), and −118(1) K for 1, 2, and (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 , respectively. This case study highlights the potential of combining octacyanidometalates and chiral building blocks and opens new perspectives in magnetochiral materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

As a part of our studies aimed at the synthesis of coordination polymers containing chiral building blocks and octacyanidometalates, we report two novel 1D helical chains [(bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3][MIV(CN)8]⋅H2O (M = Mo 1, W 2). The spiral intrinsically chiral (bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3 trinuclear nodes transfer chirality from the trinuclear nodes to the helical chains. To the best of our knowledge, the helical chains [(bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3][MIV(CN)8]⋅H2O are the first examples of the presence of polynuclear chiral building blocks in octacyanidometalate-based systems. Magnetic studies of 1, 2, and previously reported [(bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3]I4⋅CH3OH ((LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 ) reveal antiferromagnetic interactions inside the (bdapH)2(bdap)2CuII 3 units with J values equal to -100(2), -100(2), and -118(1) K for 1, 2, and (LH)  2 L  2  Cu  3  I  4 , respectively. This case study highlights the potential of combining octacyanidometalates and chiral building blocks and opens new perspectives in magnetochiral materials.

elements.content:
Dedicated to Professor Marius Andruh on the occasion of his 60th birthday.

Experimental data for (LH) 2 ­L 2 Cu 3 I 4 , ORTEP diagram of structural motifs of 1 and 2, local environment of metal centers, hydrogen-bond network, SHAPE parameters for CuII and MIV centers, diffuse reflectance solid-state UV–vis-NIR spactra of 1 and 2, and results of photomagnetic studies. X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) are available for compounds 1 and 2. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

[(bdapH)<sub>2</sub>­(bdap)<sub>2</sub>­Cu<sup>II</sup> <sub>3</sub>]­[Mo<sup>IV</sup>­(CN)<sub>8</sub>]·​H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

To the aqueous solution (16 mL) containing Cu­(ClO4)2·​6H2O (37 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1,3-diamino-2-propanol (45 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added K4­[Mo­(CN)8]·​2H2O (25 mg, 0.05 mmol, 4 mL of H2O) slowly upon vigorous stirring. The dark blue solution was left undisturbed for slow evaporation in a dark place. Navy blue crystals of 1 were obtained after a few weeks. The product was filtrated, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield of 1: 21.8 mg (75% based on Cu). Elementary Anal. Calcd. for C20H40­Cu3­MoN16O5 (871.21 g/mol): C, 27.57; H, 4.63; N, 25.72%; found: C, 27.36; H, 4.67; N, 25.64%. IR of 1 (KBr, cm–1): 3462s(br), 3303vs(br) [ν(O–H), ν(N–H)]; 3125m, 2924m, 2880w, 2851m [ν(C–H)]; 2124vs, 2109m, 2096vs, 2083vs [ν(CN)]; 1600s, 1574s [γ(O–H)]; 1452m, 1413w, 1385w, 1353w, 1330w, 1307m, 1285w, 1219w [δ(H–C–H), ν(N–C), ν(C–C)]; 1187m, 1151w, 1086m, 1049s, 1027s, 962m, 931w, 893w, 847m, 803s, 731s, 635w [γ(N–H out-of-plane), ν(N–C)]; 537m, 505m [ν(Mo–C), ν(Cu–N)]. Solid-state UV–vis-NIR of 1 (nm): 256, 369 [MLCT band of [Mo­(CN)8]4–]; 430 [MMCT band in Cu(II)-Mo(IV) pair]; 710, 823 [d–d bands of (LH)2­L2Cu3] (, Figure S4).

[(bdapH)<sub>2</sub>­(bdap)<sub>2</sub>­Cu<sup>II</sup> <sub>3</sub>]­[W<sup>IV</sup>­(CN)<sub>8</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

An analogous procedure to that of 1 was applied, but K4­[W­(CN)8]·​2H2O (29 mg, 0.05 mmol) instead of K4­[Mo­(CN)8]·​2H2O was used. Yield of 2: 20.5 mg (64% based on Cu). Elementary Anal. Calcd. for C20H40­Cu3­N16O5W (959.11 g/mol): C, 25.05; H, 4.20; N, 23.37%; found: C, 24.93; H, 4.40; N, 23.44%. IR of 2 (KBr, cm–1): 3473s(br), 3303vs(br) [ν(O–H), ν(N–H)]; 3127m, 2924m, 2880w, 2851m [ν(C–H)]; 2124vs, 2110m, 2091vs, 2074vs [ν(CN)]; 1600s, 1574s [γ(O–H)]; 1454m, 1412w, 1384w, 1352w, 1331w, 1308m, 1284w, 1220w [δ(H–C–H), ν(N–C), ν(C–C)]; 1186m, 1150w, 1085m, 1047s, 1028s, 961m, 930w, 895w, 845m, 800s, 731s, 634w [γ(N–H out–of–plane), ν(N–C)]; 538m, 483m [ν(W–C), ν(Cu–N)]. Solid-state UV–vis-NIR of 2 (nm): 250, 277, 370 [MLCT band of [Mo­(CN)8]4–]; 433 [MMCT band in Cu(II)-W(IV) pair]; 710, 831 [d–d bands of (LH)2­L2Cu3] (, Figure S4).

cln_elements.content: Left: the 1D left- (Λ) and right-handed (Δ) helical chains of 1 and 2. Colors used: [M­(CN)8]4–, green; Cu2+, orange; bdapH, magenta; and water, yellow. Right: crystal packing along a axis. Colors used: left-handed helix (Λ), black; right-handed helix (Δ), light gray.
